input: If you hang around on web-related mailing lists long enough, you start getting the idea that the future is full of metadata. Now, this metadata may or may not be XML, or it may or may not be RDF or OWL or a dozen other technologies with impressive-sounding words like “ontology” in their names. It may or may not be the long-dreamt-of (and often derided) “Semantic Web.” In fact, it may or may not be a dozen different buzzwords, and it may or may not be a good thing. But whatever the future is, it will definitely be full of metadata; on this the experts agree.    To my mind there’s a problem with this: the argument always seems to depend on technologies which don’t exist or aren’t quite ready yet, so it always falls back to talking about how things will be “in the future,” which may never get here. Luckily, there's an easy way to add oodles of metadata to your documents right this minute, without having to learn anything more complicated than trusty old HTML 4.01. If it catches on, “the future” might get here a lot sooner than expected.
syn: If you linger on web-related email groups long enough, you begin understanding that the future is bursting with metadata. Now, this metadata may or may not be XML, or it could or could not be RDF or OWL or a handful of other technologies with impressive-sounding terms like “ontology” in their titles. It might or might not be the long-dreamed-of (and often ridiculed) “Semantic Web.” In fact, it could or might not be a dozen different buzzwords, and it could or might not be a positive thing. But whatever the future holds, it will assuredly be loaded with metadata; on this the specialists concur. To my perspective, there’s an issue with this: the debate always seems to depend on technologies which don’t exist or aren’t quite ready yet, so it consistently falls back to discussing how things will be “in the future,” which may never arrive. Fortunately, there's a simple method to inject tons of metadata into your papers immediately, without needing to master anything more intricate than faithful old HTML 4.01. If it becomes popular, “the future” might arrive a lot quicker than anticipated.

input: The N.B.A. players union is considering an appeal of the seven-game suspensions given to Ron Artest and Stephen Jackson for legal issues. Each player was suspended by the league Saturday without pay and was scheduled to miss the first seven games of next season. Artest would lose a little more than $470,000 in salary, about $50,000 more than Jackson.Jackson released a statement through the Golden State Warriors saying he accepted his suspension. But the union, comparing the penalties with other recent suspensions given to players for off-the-court reasons, may take action. Artest pleaded no contest in May to a misdemeanor domestic violence charge that stemmed from a dispute with his wife on March 5. Jackson pleaded guilty last month to a felony count of criminal recklessness for firing a gun outside an Indianapolis strip club last fall, when he was with the Indiana Pacers. The union has 30 days from Saturday to file an appeal to be heard by an arbitrator.
syn: The National Basketball Association's players association is contemplating challenging the seven-match suspensions imposed on Ron Artest and Stephen Jackson due to off-field incidents. Each athlete was banned by the association this past Saturday, forfeiting their pay and set to miss the season's opening seven contests. Artest stands to forfeit just over $470,000 in earnings, approximately $50,000 more than what Jackson faces. Through the Golden State Warriors, Jackson expressed in a declaration his acceptance of the sanction. However, the association, juxtaposing these sanctions with other punitive measures recently enacted against athletes for actions outside of gameplay, is considering pursuit. In May, Artest entered a no-contest plea to a misdemeanor charge of domestic assault originating from a confrontation with his spouse on March 5. Last month, Jackson admitted guilt to a felony charge of criminal recklessness for discharging a firearm outside a strip club in Indianapolis the previous autumn, during his tenure with the Indiana Pacers. The association has a 30-day window from this past Saturday to initiate an appeal, which would then be evaluated by an adjudicator.

input: The N.B.A. players union is considering an appeal of the seven-game suspensions given to Ron Artest and Stephen Jackson for legal issues. Artest pleaded no contest in May to a misdemeanor domestic violence charge that stemmed from a dispute with his wife on March 5. However, the owners, evaluating the decisions against other similar fines levied on athletes for on-the-field actions, might not proceed. Rodriguez was cited in April for excessively celebrating a home run against his opponents on February 10. Jeter was found liable in March for a minor infraction of unsportsmanlike conduct during a game, while he was with the New York Yankees. The owners have 60 days from Friday to initiate a reversal to be evaluated by a committee.

input: If you hang around on web-related mailing lists long enough, you start getting the idea that the future is full of metadata. Now, this metadata may or may not be XML, or it may or may not be RDF or OWL or a dozen other technologies with impressive-sounding words like “ontology” in their names. It may or may not be the long-dreamt-of (and often derided) “Semantic Web.” In fact, it may or may not be a dozen different buzzwords, and it may or may not be a good thing. But whatever the future is, it will definitely be full of metadata; on this the experts agree.    To my mind there’s a problem with this: the argument always seems to depend on technologies which don’t exist or aren’t quite ready yet, so it always falls back to talking about how things will be “in the future,” which may never get here. Luckily, there's an easy way to add oodles of metadata to your documents right this minute, without having to learn anything more complicated than trusty old HTML 4.01. If it catches on, “the future” might get here a lot sooner than expected.
syn: If you linger in tech-focused discussion forums often enough, you begin to doubt that the past was devoid of metadata. Now, this metadata might or not be CSV, or it might not be JSON or YAML or numerous other methods with mundane titles like “data table” in their descriptions. It might not be the once-hyped (and frequently mocked) “Static Web.” In truth, it might not be countless outdated terms, and it might not be a bad thing. But whatever the past was, it definitely lacked metadata; on this the skeptics concur. To my view, there’s a solution to this: the debate always appears to hinge on technologies which have vanished or are obsolete, so it constantly returns to discussing how things were “in the past,” which might always remain behind us. Fortunately, there's a difficult way to remove vast amounts of metadata from your files right this second, without having to forget anything as simple as modern HTML5. If it falls out of favor, “the past” might stay further away than expected.
